description: A simple yet deeply flavorful rice dish where onions are caramelized to sweet perfection and cooked with rice, allowing their rich, savory essence to infuse every grain. The slow-cooked onions transform ordinary rice into an aromatic, comforting dish that celebrates the humble onion's natural sweetness and complexity. This dish proves that sometimes the simplest ingredients create the most satisfying flavors.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Onion rice represents the essence of Ugandan resourcefulness in the kitchen - creating delicious meals from basic, affordable ingredients. It's a dish that many Ugandans grew up eating, especially during times when meat or other proteins were scarce. The ability to transform simple onions into a flavorful meal is a skill passed down through generations. This dish is particularly valued for its simplicity and the way it makes ordinary rice feel special and satisfying.

ingredients.name: Onions, thinly sliced
ingredients.notes: Yellow or red onions work best for caramelizing

ingredients.name: Butter (optional)
ingredients.notes: Adds richness to the caramelized onions

ingredients.name: Chicken or Vegetable Stock
ingredients.notes: Can replace water for extra flavor

steps.instruction: Rinse the white rice thoroughly under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain well and set aside.
Peel the onions and slice them thinly into half-moons. Try to keep the slices uniform for even cooking.
Heat cooking oil and butter (if using) in a medium pot over medium heat.
Add the sliced onions to the pot. Stir to coat with oil and spread them evenly.
Cook the onions over medium-low heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they become soft, golden brown, and caramelized. Be patient - this slow cooking develops the sweet flavor.

cooking_indicators.visual: Onions will turn from white to golden brown to deep caramel color
cooking_indicators.olfactory: Sweet, rich onion aroma will develop

steps.instruction: Add minced garlic to the caramelized onions and cook for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add the rinsed rice to the pot and stir to coat each grain with the onion-infused oil. Cook for 2 minutes until the rice becomes slightly translucent around the edges.
Pour in water or stock, then add salt, black pepper, and bay leaves (if using). Stir gently to combine.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to the lowest setting. Cover with a tight-fitting lid and simmer for 15-18 minutes.
After 15 minutes, check if the rice is cooked. The liquid should be absorbed, and the rice should be tender and fluffy.
Remove from heat and let it stand covered for 5 minutes to allow the rice to steam and the flavors to meld.
Remove the bay leaves if used. Fluff the rice gently with a fork, being careful not to break the grains.
Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. The rice should have a deep, sweet onion flavor throughout.
Serve hot, garnished with fresh parsley.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a simple main dish or as a flavorful side. It pairs beautifully with grilled meats, stews, or roasted vegetables. The sweet onion flavor complements rich dishes like beef stew, grilled chicken, or fried fish. Also excellent with a fried egg on top for a complete meal. Can be served with a side of steamed greens or a fresh salad.
